projectDesc.p: To the tune “Spring of the Brocade Hall”—"Drooping hair-bun, I am too listless to comb it" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Spring of the Brocade Hall”
Drooping hair-bun, I am too listless to comb it;

Frowning eyebrows
The literal translation is “Frowning silkworm moth tentacles”. “Silkworm moth tentacles” (蛾) refers to women’s beautiful eyebrows due to their resemblance in shape., I am too tired to draw them.
In my heart, everything is dim and declining.
I have noticed that recently I have been weary,

My gold-thread gown
Refers to beautiful clothes. The image of “gold-thread gown” comes from an anonymous poem in Tang Dynasty: I need to persuade you that you shouldn’t cherish gold-thread gowns, but to cherish youthful years. When there’re flowers on branches you should pick those flowers; don’t wait until the flower withers, and you could only pick an empty branch.” hangs loose.
I know that this man, frivolous and arrogant at heart,
talked in front of others as if nothing had happened.
I should fix the makeup on my flower-like face—
failing my youthful years like this,
how can I live with myself?
As usual, he broke his promises.
He indeed deceived me then,

making me secretly cut off a lock of hair
Cutting off a lock of one’s hair and giving it to the man is a token for love and intimate bond. for him.
When I see him return,
I will shut the door of my fragrant chamber.
Wait till he wants

to cozy up in cloud-and-rain
“Cloud and rain” alludes to a song, Song of Gao Tang (高唐赋), written by Song Yu 宋玉, who lived during the Warring States period (453–221 BCE). The Song of Gao Tang narrates a brief love affair between the Huai King of Chu 楚怀王 and a mountain fairy which takes place in the king’s dream; in this dream, the mountain fairy describes her residence after their lovemaking as “made from the cloud in the morning, but comprised of rain in the evening”. The imagery of cloud and rain is often used as a euphemism for sexual intercourse in Chinese poetry.,
I will wrap myself in the embroidered quilt,

refusing to share joy
This is a euphemism for sex. with him.
When the night is late,
I will ask him slowly,
“From now on, do you dare to be so unreasonable?”
